title-group.article-title: New Ideas Versus Bureaucratic Power in School Finance

abstract.p: Researchers at SUNY proposed Short-Lived Unanticipated Grants (SLUGs) as a way to overcome the fungibility of previous school finance equalization programs. This paper discusses how to appropriately model the effects of SLUGs on school districts. It examines the implementation of SLUGs in Connecticut to determine to what extent the political process distorted the reform. It finds the detailed state micro-management of school finance changed the nature of the aid from that envisaged in the original SLUG proposal. The paper examines special interest explanations to determine whether these interests might have significant influence on the operation of SLUGs. By analyzing some of the details of the complex provisions of Connecticut's Education Enhancement reform the paper finds substantial evidence that supply side interests influence the school finance system.
